overview: This subject focuses on both the general principles of veterinary clinical practice and the specific approach to diagnosis, management and prevention of disease in horses. Content will be delivered in blocks based on clinical presentations related to dermatologic, ophthalmic, reproductive, neonatal, locomotory and respiratory problems in parallel with presentations of the same systems in other species. This approach is designed to support students in the development of their diagnostic reasoning skills, and encourage a comparative view of veterinary medicine and surgery.
intended learning outcomes: Collect and interpret information from clinical history, epidemiological data and clinical examination findings in horses in order to develop a problem list and appropriate differential diagnoses related to dermatologic, ophthalmic, reproductive, neonatal, locomotory and respiratory presentations
Select and interpret diagnostic testing in order to establish a definitive diagnosis in horses with dermatologic, ophthalmic, reproductive, neonatal, locomotory and respiratory presentations

Evaluate and integrate information from a range of sources in order to make recommendations for preventative health care strategies for common and important equine diseases and to prevent transmission of disease to other horses or humans, taking into account prognostic, economic and animal welfare considerations while adhering to professional and ethical standards for both companion and competition horses

additional pre-requisite: Satisfactory completion of all subjects at DVM 2 level

assessments.description: Written examination. 2 hours. Hurdle requirement:. Students must achieve a minimum mark of 40% in the written examination to be eligible to pass the subject.
Aggregate Mark. Hurdle requirement:. Students must pass the subject on aggregate mark.

Semester 1 (Early-Start).Contact hours: 40 hours of lectures, practical classes and workshops

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
